elements.text: PART ONE
Scene 1: INT. TARDIS, CONTROL ROOM
FX: B/G TARDIS IN FLIGHT
FX: DOCTOR ENTERS FROM INTERNAL DOOR

(LICKING FINGERS) The final slice. And I must say, Evelyn, that sponge is one of your greatest- (BREAKS OFF, REALISING HE’S ALONE) triumphs... Ah. (BEAT, SADLY) The last piece of chocolate cake... and nobody to bake any more...
FX: WALKS TO CONSOLE, PRESSES CONTROLS
(MOROSE) ‘All the world's a stage,
And all the men and women merely players:
They have their exits-’ (BREAKS OFF)
Exit Dr Smythe. Oh, Evelyn.
‘They have their exits.. and their entrances...’
(BEAT, COMES TO DECISION) It’s time, I think. Time for Pease Pottage. Time for Miss Melanie Bush.
FX: DEMATERIALISATION
‘And one man in his time plays many parts...’
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 3
Scene 2: INT. PEASE POTTAGE VILLAGE HALL
(FX: CLAPPING HANDS) From the beginning, everybody, if you’d be so kind?
FX: SHORT PIANO INTRO, PAUSE
(CALLING) Master Thurwell? That was your cue.
(CALLING FROM BACKSTAGE) He’s not here, Mr Petherbridge.
Thank you, Melanie. Very well. I’1l1 have words with that boy
about his timekeeping.
Let us press on without him. Mrs Wilberforce, if you wouldn’t mind. From the top.
FX: SHORT PIANO INTRO
At this point Master Thurwell will enter, with his band of brigands, and perform their part in proceedings.
FX: SHORT PIANO OUTRO
Then Mrs Wilberforce and the stout ladies of the W I. will give their demonstration.
Not so much of the stout, Mr Petherbridge.
I do of course use it in the strong and steadfast sense. Though after your Victoria sponge, Muriel, the other meaning will apply to the rest of us.
(LAUGHING) Oh, Mr Petherbridge...
Miss Bush takes the stage.
FX: SHORT PIANO INTRO, YOUNG MEL WALKING ON STAGE
And cue Melanie-
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 4
(RECITING) Pease Pottage hot, Pease Pottage cold. Pease Pottage in the pot, nine days old.
Some like it hot-
FX: NOISY LORRY REVVING OUTSIDE
(STRUGGLING ON OVER NOISE) Some like it cold. Some like it in the pot-
No, no, no. This is no good. No good at all. (FX: THROWS DOWN PAPERS) Excuse me, ladies. (FX: WALKS OFF THROUGH DOORS)
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 5
Scene 3: EXT. OUTSIDE VILLAGE HALL
FX: LORRY REVVING — REVERSING BEEP
Hello? Hello? I say in there. Didn’t you see the signs? Pease Pottage is closed to traffic.
(CALLING DOWN FROM CAB) It’s ridiculous. You lot can’t do this.
There is a Heritage event. The village has diversions in place. In any case, this is a cul de sac.
I know that now. What are you lot up to? Those ain’t official Signs back there.
You were supposed to turn off at the roundabout.
Why are the services closed? You can’t shut down the A23.. It’s miles out of me way up the A264.
Then I suggest you backtrack and take the London Road to Cuckfield and Bolney.
Down those country lanes? It’s hard enough turning this thing around here...
The road less travelled can make all the difference... And it is the traditional route.
Look. I pay my taxes to Maggie like everyone else. I’ve every right to drive down here. Hoity-toity old busybodies... You just don’t want the likes of me messing up your-
FX: DINOSAUR ROAR AND CHARGING FOOTFALL
‘Ere. What was that?
FX: DINOSAUR ROAR AND CHARGING FOOTFALL — MUCH CLOSER
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 6
Alternatively, you could rejoin the main road at Handcross...
FX: ROAR AND CLANG AS DINOSAUR ATTACKS LORRY
Ah. I suspect it’s all rather academic now...
What the hell’s that? A monster? Help me! Get it away... It can’t be...
FX: LORRY BEING MANGLED, SCREAM OF DRIVER
Iguanodon, I believe. Early Cretacious. It’s actually a herbivore. Still, very territorial.
FX: DINOSAUR ROAR AND CHARGING FOOTFALL
Oh, there’s another one.
FX: LORRY BEING MANGLED, SCREAM OF DRIVER
Really. They never think of the effect on the environment. Someone’s going to have to clear that up.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 7
Scene 4: INT. PEASE POTTAGE VILLAGE HALL
(FX: LORRY MANGLING OFF, DOORS OPEN BRIEFLY LETTING IN NOISE, PETHERBRIDGE ENTERS )
Everything all right, Mr Petherbridge?
Yes, Mrs Wilberforce. Another of those monstrosities.
They think they own the roads. Coming though here, with their sixteen-wheels.. If I’d been here when they built that motorway, I’d certainly have had something to say!
FX: NOISES OUTSIDE STOP
That’s better. Now, Melanie. Where were we, my dear?
FX: SHORT PIANO INTRO
Pease Pottage hot, Pease Pottage cold. Pease Pottage in the pot
eight days old...
MUSIC SEGUE TO:
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 8
Scene 5: EXT. DOWNVIEW CRESCENT, PEASE POTTAGE
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISATION, DOOR UNLOCKS
(EXITING TARDIS) Here we are, Mel. Pease Pottage, West Sussex. Late nineteen-eighties. Your proper place in space and time.
(EXITING TARDIS) Pease Pottage? But Doctor-
FX: DOCTOR AND MEL WALKING BRISKLY THROUGH FOLLOWING
Hush! Melanie. Not another word.
(RUSHING TO CATCH UP) But I don’t think Pease Pottage is-
(REACTS, INTERRUPTING) Shhh!
We weren’t in Pease Pottage when-
(REACTS, INTERRUPTING) Please Mel. I’ve already seen far too much of my own future. My people take a very dim view. I don’t want to exit one trial just to be hauled in front of another!
Can’t we just carry on? Pick up where we left off?
That’s the problem. I am not where you left off. I haven’t even met you yet. Somewhere out there’s a future version of me with
whom you should be travelling.
That’s what I’m trying to tell you — he’1ll be waiting on [Oxyveguramosa]-
(REACTS, INTERRUPTING) Shh! Not another syllable passes those lips until I am out of earshot. This is precisely what I’m talking about. I should know nothing more about my future movements.
But shouldn’t you take me [back?]
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 9

(INTERRUPTING) Mel! The safest course of action is for me to leave you here. Home. My future self will be fully aware of this and know exactly where to find you. Assuming he’s still disposed to do so.
What do you mean...?
Quite how I put up with the constant badgering and carrot-—based cordials.. I really don’t know.
Yes, you do seem a little... different from my Doctor. More... bolshy.
Bolshy? Bolshy!? Revolutionary, perhaps... (STOPPING) Ah. Downview Crescent. This is your address is it not?
Yes, but-
Good. Off you pop. Go home. Sit tight. Liquidise a root vegetable. Do some... ‘aerobics’. Whatever takes your fancy. I’m sure your ‘less bolshy’ Doctor will be along presently.
I suppose it makes sense. I should wait for the right Doctor...
When am I ever wrong?
It would be nice to see Mum and Dad...
(WALKING AWAY) That’s the spirit.
(JUST OFF) Well, thanks for the ride.
(HURRYING AWAY) And thank you for the... er.. testimony. Au revoir Mel!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 10
(CALLING, FROM OFF) Goodbye Doctor!
FX: SWIFT WALKING AWAY

There. I did it. (CALLING OUT, AS IF TO THE TIME LORDS) I did it! No more interference in the timelines. Though why I’m worried about you lot, I don’t know. Far too busy rigging elections for the new High Council I imagine...
At last. I can relax.
FX: BIRDSONG — SONG THRUSH
‘That’s the wise thrush; he sings each song twice over Lest you should think he never could recapture
The first fine careless rapture!’

(STOPPING) That’s odd. Beyond that hedgerow is one of the busiest arterial thoroughfares in Southern England. It’s summer. A beautiful morning... Yet all I hear is birdsong. (SNIFFING) But I smell... diesel... And see smoke. Right.
FX: JOGGING DOWN ROAD
(RUNNING) Why, oh why can’t I simply drop somebody off without... complications? Note to self. Never, ever drive a taxi.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 11
Scene 6: INT. MEL’S HOUSE
FX: FRONT DOOR UNLOCKS AND OPENS
(CALLING) Mum? Dad? I’m back!
FX: CAT PADDING IN, MEOW
Hello. What are you doing here? Sneaked in through the kitchen window, eh? That’s what old Tibbie from number thirty-two used to do.
(CALLING) Mum! (BEAT) Nobody home. Just you and me.
FX: PERSISTENT MEOWS
Actually you look exactly like Tibbie.. She did that too...
FX: PURRING
It is you isn’t it? But you died six months before I even met the Doctor. (GROANS) He’s brought me back to the wrong time.
FX: DOORBELL
That’1ll be him. He must have realised.
FX: OPENING FRONT DOOR
Doctor.
Good morning, Miss Bush. Allow me to introduce myself. I am... known as the-(BREAKS OFF, CONFUSED)
Doctor. That’s what I said.
Oh no.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 12
Scene 7: EXT. OUTSIDE VILLAGE HALL
FX: DOCTOR SHIFTING METAL BITS OF LORRY
This was no mere traffic accident. The cab’s been completely
crushed. (FX: WRENCHING DOOR AWAY) Ah. And the occupant. Alas poor Yorkie... You've had your last chunky chocolate bar. Hmm.
What have we here?
FX: PULLING FRAGMENT OUT OF METAL
A piece of tooth? No... a claw. Possibly Ornithiscian... Iguanodon bernissartensis if I’m not mistaken.
FX: BICYCLE APPROACHING & RINGING BELL
And the trail leads across the road. (STEPS OFF PAVEMENT) Now what’s an iguanodon doing in nineteen-eighty-[nine]
FX: COLLISION AS BIKE RUNS INTO DOCTOR
(FALLING TO GROUND) Oof!
Sorry. You just walked out in front of me! Are you hurt?
The only casualty is my dignity. I think. (GETTING UP) Ow.
Didn’t you ever learn the Green Cross Code?
Pardon me for being preoccupied by the pulverised pantechnicon peppering the pavement. (BEAT) Mel?
(CAUTIOUS) That’s right.. Who are you?
You don’t know me?
Should I?
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 13
Perhaps not.. Tell me. What year is this?
I must have hit you harder than I thought! 1987.
(TO SELF) Am I too early..?
No, we've been here since quarter to eight. Mr Petherbridge is still in the hall if you want to see him.
Mr Petherbridge?
Head of the Dramatic Society. And the Heritage Society. And the Village Association. (BEAT) Is it ‘Joseph’?
(CONFUSED) No. I am known as the Doctor...
I mean the ‘coat of many colours’? You’re here to audition aren’t you? Sorry, I’ve got to get to work. If you’re sure you’re OK...
Yes, yes. I should probably make a note of your place of employment should any... complications arise.
I’m at the radar station. The ATC, up by the school. Sorry, it’s nearly nine...
Of course. You seem a very trustworthy young lady. I’1l be in touch should I require your... assistance.
(GETTING BACK ON BIKE) Good luck with the technicolour dreamcoat. You could try Brighton. They’1ll be casting their summer seasons. Bye! (FX: MEL CYCLES OFF)
How serendipitous. Perhaps now is the time I’m supposed to meet Mel the younger? Pease Pottage radar station. As good a place as any to hone her burgeoning computer skills.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 14
There’s just the small matter of the prehistoric talon in this wreckage. Wreckage which Mel spectacularly failed to notice. How peculiar.
Can I help you? Mister..?
Good morning Madam. I was just considering alerting the authorities. There are this poor fellow’s earthly remains to dispose of.
I suppose you think you’re very modern, don’t you? Spouting this nonsense?
FX: WIBBLY DISTORTION AS LORRY DISAPPEARS
I’m sorry?
It might work for auditions up in that there London. But it cuts no ice out here in the real world!
Excuse me. As you can see, there’s been a not insignificant incident-
Where?
Well, right here!
Right where?
Here. This vehicle has been completely- (TURNS ROUND) Impossible. It’s gone. Right from under my nose. (BEAT) Madam, may I-

(INTERRUPTING) I can’t waste my morning bandying words with a fellow in fancy dress who clearly doesn’t know what day it is. Some of us have jams to jar and post offices to open. (GOING OFF, CALLING) I suggest you drive yourself straight back to London. And a haircut wouldn’t go amiss, while you’re about it. Good day.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 15
I was only going to ask if I could borrow this bike. (FX: PICKING UP BICYCLE)
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 16
Scene 8: EXT. MEL’S HOUSE, DOORSTEP
So Mel, you know who I am?
Of course I do, Doctor. You just- (BREAKS OFF) What are you wearing?
This is my usual attire.
But your coat...
The blue? Rather dignified I thought.
It’s a bit understated... sombre... boring! Not you at all. I have to say I prefer the patchwork. At least it’s got a bit of pizzazz.
You really are a child of the Eighties, aren’t you Mel? But what are you doing here? Shouldn’t you be off travelling with a future Doctor?
That’s what the other you said. When he left me here to meet you. I mean, not you... some other you.
The.. other me? Oh no. I’ve crossed my own timestream.
(WORKING IT OUT) So you’re older than that Doctor... but younger than mine.
This is potentially disastrous.
Just because I’ve told you you’re wearing the wrong coat?
Intersecting timestreams have far greater repercussions than my sartorial decisions.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 17
So. What next, Indigo Jones?
Indigo? It’s Inigo, Mel. I’d have thought someone with your perfect recall-
(INTERRUPTING) I know. I was making a joke.
That’s a matter of opinion. Now, I distinctly remember taking you back to- Wait. Where is he? The earlier Doctor?
You’ve only just missed yourself. He went- (BREAKS OFF) Actually. Are you supposed to do that?
Not usually, no. But it’s not just any me. Not one of those other fellows with their scarves and frills and.. (DISDAINFUL) celery. It’s me me! I’1l be more than capable of handling the Situation.
But if you’re older... wouldn’t you remember meeting yourself?
Thank you Mel. Just... forget you saw me. I’1l be along later!
FX: FRONT DOOR CLOSES
What do I do now? Wait for another one to turn up?
FX: MEOW
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 18
Scene 9: INT. ATC STATION
(FX: B/G LOTS OF COMPUTER NOISE, WHIRRS, BEEPS, AND BLIP OF RADAR)
Tracking... Two hundred and sixty thousand feet and descending. Wonderful. We shall see you very soon.
FX: DOOR OPENS
Ah, young Melanie. Bright and early and ready for another day at the forefront of... traffic control?
Beat me again, Mr Petherbridge! I never know how you manage it!
At my age, it’s important to remain sprightly. You never know when you might need a turn of speed.
I had an excuse today. Bumped into someone outside the hall. Literally. Here to audition from the look of him.
Really? We do see all sorts passing though. I’d hoped the road restrictions might reduce the.. confusion. At least until the main event.
So. Where should I start today?
The whole place could do with a tidy. A general once over I think. Some pest control too.
FX: KNOCK ON DOOR
Who’s that?
(OUTSIDE DOOR) Hello? Mr P? You in there?
(DOWNBEAT) Oh. It’s Jed.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 19
Ah. Young Master Thurwell. Come to apologise for this morning’s absence, no doubt.
Well, I don’t want to see him.
A little tiff? Don’t worry. I shan’t invite him in. I think I’ll pop back to the hall. I have my mobile phone. Another run- through after lunch?
All right, Mr Petherbridge.
(GOING TO DOOR) And Melanie. This time when you’re vacuuming, please don’t unplug the computers.
I’1ll try to remember!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 20
Scene 10: EXT. OUTSIDE ATC STATION
FX: PETHERBRIDGE EXITING ATC, WALKING OVER PEBBLE PATH
Jedediah. You missed the rehearsal this morning.
Sorry Mister P. Overslept I did. The Black Swan has a fine selection of ales and an even finer selection of fillies.
Ah yes. 1970s night, wasn’t it? Melanie is most perturbed. I hope you didn’t upset her.
I never meant to. She’s a lovely girl. It’s just... those ladies were so... emancipated.
FX: THEY WALK ALONG PATH
Indeed. Now Jedediah, I’m informed that the Cinder Banks carriage will be crossing today from Parish Lane. It is vital that you waylay it and acquire the supplies.
I’‘ll need the lads, Mr P.
I’1l make sure they are available.
How... forcible d’you want it? Talkin’ of emancipation. Some of
those gents been away a long time.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 21
Scene 11: EXT. OUTSIDE ATC STATION, ALONG PATH [CONTINUOUS]
FX: DOCTOR CYCLING ALONG
(OFF) Got a lot of anger in ‘em. Liable to kick up a shindy.
(OFF) I don’t mind at all. Just be aware the cargo is potentially lethal.
(TO SELF) What have we here? Plotters, eh.
FX: DOCTOR STOPS CYCLING AND DISMOUNTS
(TO SELF) Ouch. I’m sure Mel’s handlebars left a dent.
(OFF) So the carriage’ll be horse-drawn, Mr P?
(OFF, APPROACHING) Yes. Cinder Banks usually sends four men along. Armed. But only pikes and blades.
(TO SELF) They’re coming this way.
FX: DROPS BIKE AND HIDES IN BUSHES
(PASSING BY) Poacher Pete’s got some cables from those road- diggings. He’s been settin’ all sorts of traps along the ‘Orsham road. Wants to bag a wild boar, or maybe one o’ them dragons.
(PASSING BY) Yes, well. We’re trying to clear them out.
(PASSING BY) I thought we could put one across the road... Bury it under the dirt...
(PASSING BY) Whatever you think will work, Master Thurwell. You are the criminal expert after all.
(STOPPING) What’s that doing ‘ere?
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 22
Muriel’s bicycle. The children must have taken it again.
Youths today. They’1ll pilfer anything, they will.
I sincerely hope so. (CHUCKLES) Bring it. (WALKING OFF) I need to find Mrs Wilberforce. See how preparations with her W.I. are progressing.
FX: JED PICKS UP BICYCLE AND WHEELS IT OFF
(WALKING OFF) My lads might be a band of neck-or-nothing ruffians, but I shouldn’t like to meet her lot in a dark alley.
THEY LAUGH, GOING OFF
FX: DOCTOR EMERGES FROM BUSHES
Mr P? The ubiquitous Mr Petherbridge, I presume. Now why would the chairman of the village drama group be planning a hold-up?
(FX: WALKING ALONG PEBBLE PATH) And what was that young man wearing? Historical reconstruction, perhaps? With live-action dinosaurs.
Here we are. The ATC. Perhaps young Mel can offer some assistance...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 23
Scene 12: INT. ATC STATION
FX: VACUUMING, B/G AS BEFORE
(RECITING TO HERSELF) Pease Pottage Hot, Pease Pottage cold, Pease Pottage in the pot six days old...
FX: DOCTOR KNOCKS AND ENTERS
(OVER VACUUM) Hello again, Miss Bush.
FX: VACUUM OFF
What are you doing here? No complications I hope?
Don’t worry, I’m in peak condition. Well, well, well. I’ve seen a few radar stations in my time, but never one so well- equipped. (FX: STARTS TAPPING KEYBOARD)
One might almost say over-equipped. Now what have we here...
You can’t touch that! Mr Petherbridge wouldn’t like it.
Lend a hand, Mel. Two technical brains are better than one.
I don’t think you should be doing that.. Besides, I wouldn’t have a clue.
(DISTRACTED) Really? I thought you were fluent in all- Hold on. That’s not an aeroplane.
What isn’t?
That dish outside isn’t pointed at any local flight path. No, it’s tracking something much higher in the mesosphere.
How do you know that?
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 24
And there’s an energy signal extending into the woods outside. Fifty metres west. Come on, Mel.
Come on? I’m working. I can’t just up and leave with a stranger.
FX: DISTORTED EXPLOSION, OFF
That didn’t sound good.
That’s just the time explosion. Nothing to worry about.
‘Time explosion’? I’d say that’s most definitely something to worry about.
Mr Petherbridge says it’s just an echo.
Does he now? He exerts quite an influence in these parts, this Petherbridge. (LEAVING) Perhaps it is safest you stay here, Mel. While I investigate.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 25
Scene 13: INT. MARDAK SHIP, BRIDGE
FX: SMOOTH ENGINE. ‘BING’ OF SEATBELT OFF SIGNAL
Entering atmosphere now, Captain. Scanning.
Hold her steady, pilot.
Source confirmed.
FX: COMMUNICATOR BEEP
(VIA INTERCOM) Are we there yet, Kallak?
Almost. I’ll rally the troops. You should run your presentation, Vaneesh.
(D) Actioning that now, Captain.
Looks like quite a haul for your first job.
(D) Just nice to P. O. something this big.
It’s luck, Vaneesh. This was supposed to be a training flight. But business protocols have been engaged, and you technically outrank me. Not sure you’re ready to be Project Overseer...
(D) You know how to boost a girl’s confidence, Captain.
Let’s see how you do. Remember. Mardak HomeCorp is watching.
(D) (OFF) Deerek, get my nanodrive, will you. Set up deck two.
I’1ll break out the valanxium. Open the Channel. Don’t be too long. Twenty slides max.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 26
(D) I’ve forty-seven, but I’m sure I can whip through! I thought I’d start with- (FX: COMMS BEEP AS KALLAK CUTS HER OFF)
(DISDAINFUL) Graduates...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 27
Scene 14: EXT. PEASE POTTAGE, HORSHAM ROAD
FX: WALKING FOOTSTEPS
Let’s see... Horsham Road. This way to the village, that towards... Ah. I’d recognise that motley anywhere. There I am!
FX: RUNNING FOOTSTEPS
(CALLING & CATCHING UP) Doctor! Doctor, wait!
FX: TRAP SPRUNG - WHOOSH AS BLUE DOCTOR HOISTED UP BY FEET
Aaaaargh!
(RUNNING UP FROM RIGHT) Look out! Watch your step. The road’s covered with-
(L) (CALLING DOWN) Traps. Yes. I had noticed.
(R) (SURPRISED) It’s you — I mean, me! What am I doing up there? Apart from... hanging around?
(L) (CALLING DOWN) Could you get me down please?
(R) Certainly Doctor... I presume you are a future iteration, Since I don’t recall meeting myself in a similar predicament... (BEAT) But then...
(L) (CALLING DOWN) Yes? Can you hurry it up?
(R) Just a moment. Surely my future self would be fully aware of the traps on the road and so would not be fool enough to step into one.
(L) (CALLING DOWN) You’re over-thinking. I can’t be expected to remember every little thing. We’re all allowed an off day...
(R) Why are you wearing Necros mourning colours?
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 28
(L) (CALLING DOWN) Tastes change. My demeanour certainly has. I’d forgotten I could be so... obstreperous!
(R) Given the peculiarities I’ve encountered already today... how do I know you’re not a trap? An imposter? Out to ensnare me.
(L) (CALLING DOWN) Well, I wouldn’t be doing a very good job of it up here.
(R) Something strange is going on... Right now, I’ve no idea what I’m dealing with...
(L) (CALLING DOWN) On that we agree.
(R) (SUSPICIOUS) Anyone could say they’re the Doctor. Any number of alien intelligences could contrive to look like me.
(L) Oh, for goodness sake... Perhaps a little telepathy might clear things up? (FIRM) Contact!
FX: TELEPATHIC CONFERENCE EFFECT - ‘THREE DOCTORS’
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 29
Scene 15: INT. MEL’S HOUSE
[ (FX: TV SWITCHES BETWEEN CHANNELS: NEWS
-as Mrs Thatcher starts her third term in office, we look towards-
FX: CLICK, TO EXERCISE PROGRAMME
(FX: AEROBICS MUSIC B/G) And one and two and three and four. Stretch! Again-
FX: CLICK, TO SOAP
Woss goin on, Trace? Why’d you wanna see me?
I’m ‘avin’ a baby, Mike. And it’s yours!
(FX: EASTENDERS-STYLE DUFF-DUFFS, TV SWITCHED OFF) ]
Repeats. But then, I suppose everything’s repeats for me.
FX: FRONT DOOR BEING OPENED, OFF
Now who’s this? (CALLING) Hello!
(OFF, COMING IN) Melanie, dear. Shouldn’t you be at work?
You know me?
Of course, dear. Are we going to do this every day? I’m looking after you, dear. While your parents are away.
Where are they?
An extended cruise of the Balearics. Look. Postcards. On the mantelpiece.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 30
I don’t remember them ever doing that...
Is it your memory again, or too many Malibus at the Black Swan? What time did you get in, young lady?
I’m sorry. I have no idea who you are.
Late bedtimes will take their toll. Let me see. Oh, my dear. You’ve aged overnight.
You might find this hard to believe, but I don’t think I’m the Melanie Bush you know.
Of course not dear. I see it now. You’re from her future!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 31
Scene 16: EXT. PEASE POTTAGE, HORSHAM ROAD
FX: TWO DOCTORS STRIDING QUICKLY ALONG ROAD
(R) (RUNNING TO CATCH UP) Look, I have apologised. How was know-
(L) (INTERRUPTING) Forget it. I’ve enough things already I
can’t forgive myself.
(R) I shan’t even ask...
(L) We’ll just get you back to your TARDIS, and you can be on
your way. Along here wasn’t it?
(R) Yes, but I don’t see why I should be the one to leave.
(L) Mel’s future is at stake. You must go. Now.
(R) I only came here to drop her off. After our trial. Surely
you remember?
(L) (SLOWLY) I remember the trial...
(R) And now I’ve met young Mel for the first time. Though she
seems a little... incomplete.
(L) No. I’m your future, and I haven’t met her yet. You shouldn’t be here at all. The sooner you get back in your TARDIS the better.
(R) So. Where is it?
(L) Wait a minute. This is where I landed.
(R) And where I landed.
to
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton
What have you done with my TARDIS?
(L) They’ve been stolen!
Page 32
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 33
Scene 17: INT. MEL’S HOUSE
Sorry, but.. just who are you?
Muriel Wilberforce, dear. Founding Member of the Pease Pottage Women’s Institute, and longest serving Chair. Up until 1964 anyway.

BLUE DOCTOR: (L) (CALLING DOWN) You’re over-thinking. I can’t be expected to remember every little thing. We’re all allowed an off day...
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) Why are you wearing Necros mourning colours?
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 28
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) (CALLING DOWN) Tastes change. My demeanour certainly has. I’d forgotten I could be so... obstreperous!
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) Given the peculiarities I’ve encountered already today... how do I know you’re not a trap? An imposter? Out to ensnare me.
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) (CALLING DOWN) Well, I wouldn’t be doing a very good job of it up here.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) Something strange is going on... Right now, I’ve no idea what I’m dealing with...
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) (CALLING DOWN) On that we agree.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) (SUSPICIOUS) Anyone could say they’re the Doctor. Any number of alien intelligences could contrive to look like me.
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) Oh, for goodness sake... Perhaps a little telepathy might clear things up? (FIRM) Contact!
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 29
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 15: INT. MEL’S HOUSE
DOCTOR WHO: [ (FX: TV SWITCHES BETWEEN CHANNELS: NEWS
NEWSREADER: -as Mrs Thatcher starts her third term in office, we look towards-
INSTRUCTOR: (FX: AEROBICS MUSIC B/G) And one and two and three and four. Stretch! Again-
MUCKY MIKE: Woss goin on, Trace? Why’d you wanna see me?
TRACE: I’m ‘avin’ a baby, Mike. And it’s yours!
TRACE: (FX: EASTENDERS-STYLE DUFF-DUFFS, TV SWITCHED OFF) ]
MEL: Repeats. But then, I suppose everything’s repeats for me.
MEL: Now who’s this? (CALLING) Hello!
WILBERFORCE: (OFF, COMING IN) Melanie, dear. Shouldn’t you be at work?
MEL: You know me?
WILBERFORCE: Of course, dear. Are we going to do this every day? I’m looking after you, dear. While your parents are away.
MEL: Where are they?
WILBERFORCE: An extended cruise of the Balearics. Look. Postcards. On the mantelpiece.
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 30
MEL: I don’t remember them ever doing that...
WILBERFORCE: Is it your memory again, or too many Malibus at the Black Swan? What time did you get in, young lady?
MEL: I’m sorry. I have no idea who you are.
WILBERFORCE: Late bedtimes will take their toll. Let me see. Oh, my dear. You’ve aged overnight.
MEL: You might find this hard to believe, but I don’t think I’m the Melanie Bush you know.
WILBERFORCE: Of course not dear. I see it now. You’re from her future!
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 31
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 16: EXT. PEASE POTTAGE, HORSHAM ROAD
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) (RUNNING TO CATCH UP) Look, I have apologised. How was know-
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) (INTERRUPTING) Forget it. I’ve enough things already I
BLUE DOCTOR: can’t forgive myself.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) I shan’t even ask...
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) We’ll just get you back to your TARDIS, and you can be on
BLUE DOCTOR: your way. Along here wasn’t it?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) Yes, but I don’t see why I should be the one to leave.
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) Mel’s future is at stake. You must go. Now.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) I only came here to drop her off. After our trial. Surely
MOTLEY DOCTOR: you remember?
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) (SLOWLY) I remember the trial...
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) And now I’ve met young Mel for the first time. Though she
MOTLEY DOCTOR: seems a little... incomplete.
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) No. I’m your future, and I haven’t met her yet. You shouldn’t be here at all. The sooner you get back in your TARDIS the better.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) So. Where is it?
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) Wait a minute. This is where I landed.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (R) And where I landed.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: to
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) So...
DOCTORS: What have you done with my TARDIS?
BLUE DOCTOR: (L) They’ve been stolen!
BLUE DOCTOR: Page 32
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 33
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 17: INT. MEL’S HOUSE
MEL: Sorry, but.. just who are you?
WILBERFORCE: Muriel Wilberforce, dear. Founding Member of the Pease Pottage Women’s Institute, and longest serving Chair. Up until 1964 anyway.
MEL: Why? What happened then?
WILBERFORCE: I died, dear. I was nearly eighty-one, you know.
MEL: Right. That settles it. I’m not waiting around any longer. I’m going to find the Doctor. Any Doctor.
WILBERFORCE: (FOLLOWING) Never mind a Doctor, dear. I think you need to see Mr Petherbridge.
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 34
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 18: EXT. DOWNVIEW CRESCENT [CONTINUOUS]
MEL: (WALKING. TO HERSELF.) We landed down on the main road.
MEL: What was that?
WILBERFORCE: Oh no. Not again. They’re playing havoc with the rhododendrons.
MEL: It’s coming from our back garden. Oh... my--
WILBERFORCE: Ooh. It’s got a mouthful of Mrs Peterson’s rosebush. She won’t like that.
MEL: But that’s a... au.
WILBERFORCE: Dinosaur, dear? Yes, dear. Been a lot of them hanging around Since they opened that leisure centre.
MEL: I know what it is. Spiky thumb. Flat nose. You’re an Iguanodon.
WILBERFORCE: Oh, very good, dear. I can never tell them apart.
MEL: I memorised a hundred and fifty different species when I was eight. You’re not going to eat us are you?
MEL: (FX: DINOSAUR ROAR — CUT OFF WITH A YELP, THEN ANOTHER LOUDER ROAR OF THE BARYONYX)
WILBERFORCE: No that one wouldn’t have. But this one might.
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 35
MEL: Long snout. Lots of teeth. Lots and lots of teeth.
WILBERFORCE: I think it’s seen us.
MEL: Baryonyx. Carnivorous. And fast. Run, Mrs Wilberforce. Run!
MEL: CRASH IN CLOSING THEME. CONTINUE WITH SCENE 19
MEL: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 36

elements.text: PART TWO
Scene 19: EXT. DOWNVIEW CRESCENT TO VILLAGE [CONTINUOUS]
(RUNNING) I don’t believe it.. Home for five minutes and I’m being chased down my own street by a dinosaur.
FX: JEDEDIAH WHISTLES
(CALLING, OFF) Oi! Miss Melanie. Mother Wilberforce. Over ‘ere!
(RUNNING) Jedediah. Why weren’t you at rehearsals this morning? And what on earth are you doing in Mr Beresford’s bungalow?
FX: BARYONYX ROAR, CLOSER
Got to keep my hand in. Not found a lock yet my bettys couldn’t
crack — past, present or future. Get in.
FX: THEY BUNDLE INTO HOUSE
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 37
Scene 20: INT. BERESFORD BUNGALOW [CONTINUOUS ]
FX: DOOR SLAMS, THUMP AND SCRATCHING OUTSIDE DOOR
That was a close one.
That door’s not going to last long.
He only had it repainted in spring.
Look, about last night, Melanie...
Sorry, but who are you?
FX: SCRATCHING STOPS
You can save your apologies, young man. This isn’t our Melanie.
Won’t one of you tell me what’s going on? Where’s my family? And everyone else, for that matter... What’s happened to Pease Pottage?
It’s stopped. Look out the window. What’s this fella doing?
FX: SUB-SONIC WHISTLE SOUND. DINOSAUR ROAR OUTSIDE, GOING OFF
That chap in fancy dress again.
The Doctor. He’s blowing a.. whistle? He’s drawing it off.
Don’t tell me. He’s trying out for the Pied Piper this time.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 38
Scene 21: EXT. DOWNVIEW CRESCENT [CONTINUOUS ]
(FX: DOCTOR BLOWING DOG WHISTLE — SUBSONIC SOUND BARELY AUDIBLE )
Now. You’re coming towards me. That’s good.
FX: DINOSAUR SNORTING, READY TO CHARGE
Oh no. I haven’t really thought this through.
There’s a good Baryonyx... You wouldn’t want to snack on me, I’d be terribly chewy. Besides, I’ve a bright future ahead of me.
FX: DINOSAUR ROARS AND CHARGES — WIBBLY DISTORT BEGINS
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 39
Scene 22: INT. ATC STATION
FX: B/G AS BEFORE
(TIDYING UP IN HER MIND) What a mess. That shouldn’t be there. Nor that. Aha.. That’s where you’re getting in...
FX: KNOCKING
(JUST OFF) Hello? Anyone home?
Can I help you?
I’m from the radar dish inspection authority. Come to inspect your... radar dish.
You again!
Mel! How marvellous to meet you at last.
What do you mean?
Did I say ‘at last’? I mean again.
What happened to your colours?
My coat? Oh... it’s... er... reversible...
I thought you were here for the stage show. I didn’t realise you were on official business. (FX: PICKS UP PHONE) I’11 call Mr Petherbridge.

(FX: TAPPING AT KEYBOARD) No need, young Mel... It might be state of the art to you, but I’m a past master with this sort of thing. (BEAT) Actually. There is such a thing as technological overkill. Why so much equipment?
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 40
I really don’t think you should...
(FX: BEEPS AND TAPPING KEYS) Now what’s he been up to?
Who?
I mean, where had I got to..? Tracking this ship. It’s extending a carrier beam to the edge of the woods.
That’s what you said before.
Yes, it’s all coming back to me now. I’ve the strangest feeling I’ve been here before.
You were. Half an hour ago.
(FX: COMPUTER ALARM) Now, how do I get through this firewall, Mel?
Don’t ask me. I’m a complete dunce when it comes to computers.
Really? Hmm. Curiouser and curiouser. (TO SELF) Some sort of mind control perhaps... No matter. I know who can help.
FX: DISTORTED EXPLOSION, OFF
Your ‘time explosion’ again. Where’s it coming from..?
Mr Petherbridge says the echo’s in the woods.
Right where this signal points. Now if you’d like to be of assistance, young Mel, you’re welcome to accompany me.
I shouldn’t leave the place empty. Not without letting Mr Petherbridge know.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 41
Oh well. If excitement and adventure aren’t your sort of thing...
(TEMPTED) Look... I just need to call him. I’11.. catch you up.
That’s more like the Mel I know! (LEAVING) Meet me at the main
road.
FX: TOUCH-TONE PHONE DIALLING
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 42
Scene 23: EXT. OUTSIDE VILLAGE HALL
FX: PETHERBRIDGE WALKING, 80’s MOBILE PHONE RING
Hello? (FX: UNINTELLIGIBLE MEL) Yes, Melanie.
Ah. You found how they’re getting in? Well done.
Go ahead. Seal the hole and take an early lunch. You’ve earned oh or I’m just at the hall. Come over afterwards. We’1ll run through
it again. Goodbye, Mel. (FX: PHONE OFF)
And goodbye to those prehistoric pests. Nothing beyond the seventeenth century. That should simplify matters.
And a deception, Melanie. I do believe you’re developing a mind of your own...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 43
Scene 24: INT. BERESFORD BUNGALOW
Good, that beastie’s gone. Your Doctor friend’s coming over.
FX: DOOR OPENING
Everybody in one piece? Good.
Doctor. What did you think you were doing?
K9’'s dog-whistle. Ultra-sonic or subsonic — depending on which end you blow.
Never mind ‘blowing’, you're lucky you’re still breathing. What happened to the dinosaur?
Extinct! It faded away. Like the lorry. Hello again. Mrs..?
Muriel Wilberforce. Postmistress and Chair of the Women’s Institute 1922 to 1964.
And you, young man?
Jedediah Thurwell. At your service, Mister.
That’s Doctor to you.
Jedediah? You’re not from the eighties either.
What d’ya mean? Made it all the way to 1884, I did. A ripe old age.
Mel? These persons are not from your time?
There’s nobody here who is! The only people I’ve met are ones who shouldn’t exist. Sorry. No offence.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 44
None taken dear.
This is all very sociable.. But if the dragon’s gone, I’1ll be off. Busy man. Things to do, eh Mrs W?
So you have.
Should find my own Melanie, too. Make amends. (LEAVING) Doctor. Miss. Pleasure to make your acquaintance.
Hold on a minute. (CALLING) What do you mean ‘your own Melanie’? Where are you going?
FX: JED EXITS HOUSE
Wherever it is, he’s in rather a hurry. So, Mrs Wilberforce, you seem to be fully aware of your situation. Why are you here?
It’s for the greater good. We’ve had to put up with a lot, but it will all be worth it in the end.
Worth it? For what?
(EVASIVE) You’re probably best asking Mr Petherbridge.
I intend to. Now excuse us. Mel and I have an appointment.
Have we?
(LEADING HER OUT) Come along.
(OFF) I’1l tidy up here. Poor Mr Beresford. His water feature will never be the same.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 45
Scene 25: EXT. DOWNVIEW CRESCENT [CONTINUOUS ]
FX: CLOSING FRONT DOOR AND WALKING DOWN STREET
What’s going on, Doctor? I met another you. Wearing blue.
So did I, Mel. And both our TARDISes have been spirited away. We’ll have to sort this mess out together. He’s fetching the other Mel and meeting us on the Horsham road.
The... other Mel?
Yes. A younger version of you. Only she’s not quite... erm...
Not quite what?
Well, I haven’t met you yet, so it’s tricky to say. One thing we do know, though... Pease Pottage has been taken out of time!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 46
Scene 26: EXT. PARISH LANE, PEASE POTTAGE
FX: CREEPING ALONG UNDERGROWTH
Hello lads. Been waiting long?
Happy to lie down here all week, Jed lad. It’s good to be free.
Freedom comes at a price though, Pete. Ready for a dustup?
You knows us, Jedediah. Always. Still don’t comprehend how you sprung us, lad.
Yeah, I’m wondering how I managed that meself.
FX: RUMBLE OF APPROACHING HORSE-DRAWN CART
(CALLING) Hear that, boys? That’s the sound of my ship coming in.
What’s our prize? An ‘undred guineas? Two?
Shut your bone box. It’s here.
FX: CART PASSING CLOSE
Pull on the ropes!
FX: HORSE REARING
Whoa there! What’s going- [on?]
(FX: COMMOTION AS BRIGANDS ATTACK CARRIAGE, DRIVER AND GUARDS DRAGGED DOWN, PUNCHED AND KICKED INTO SUBMISSION)
That’s enough lads. Truss ‘em up, and leave ‘em there. Mr P will get the mess cleared up.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 47
Sure we can’t rough ‘em up a bit more?
FX: ANOTHER KICK, HORSE WHINNIES
A good strong daisy-kicker too. Fetch a pretty penny at market. Whenever the market might be. There, there. Calm down, missy.
(FX: OPENING WOODEN CRATE) What’s this, Jedediah? Nothing but dust in these crates.
FX: DISTORTION AS GUARDS DISAPPEAR
Where’d those soldiers go?
Told you they’d get tidied up.
FX: DISTORTION AS CONVICTS DISAPPEAR
Where’s Light-fingered John? Freddy the Fists?
Back where you belong, my boys. On the wagon to Lewes Prison.
What you done to us, Jedediah? Sold us down the- (FX: DISTORT AS PETE DISAPPEARS )
Now to get this cart up to the field and unload. Sorry, Pete, in this world a body’s gotta look after his own skin. Ain’t that right missy?
FX: HORSE WHINNY
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 48
Scene 27: EXT. HORSHAM ROAD, PEASE POTTAGE
(WALKING) Do keep up, Mel. I thought you were the exercise fan.
(CATCHING UP) Excuse me if I’m a little confused.
FX: RUSTLING BUSHES AS BLUE DOCTOR EMERGES
Doctor!
(L) Well done, Doctor. I knew I could rely on you.
(R) Not at all, Doctor. A pleasure to be working with you.
I’ve heard of self-congratulation but this is ridiculous!
(L) Hello again, Mel. Two of you and two of me... This could get confusing.
(R) Not at all. This is the Mel I deposited here for our future self to collect — let’s call her Melanie A, shall we?
I am here, you know.
(R) And the younger version is Mel B...
What if another me turns up? Who’s she? Mel C?
(L) No! That cannot be allowed to happen!
(R) Yes, wrong decade for the Spice Girls...
(L) A miscellany of Melanies could herald the collapse of reality. The fabric of the cosmos... ripped apart.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 49
Where is this younger me?
(L) On her way. It seems we have two different problems to solve and four ways in which to solve them.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 50
Scene 28: EXT. OUTSIDE VILLAGE HALL
FX: JED LEADING HORSE AND CART
Ah, Master Thurwell. Went the day well?
All according to plan Mr P. Only...
Yes?
Didn’t feel right. Befooling my boys like that.
Don’t worry yourself, lad. It’1ll all be worth it in the end. Leave the cart on the green. You’1ll need the horse.
Right. (UNTYING HORSE) There’s a few crates of black powder left here. Like you said. Rest have gone in them ‘oles.
Ah yes, we still need to dig those holes... Let me see, the golf course arrives in the 1970s...
FX: VAN DRIVING UP, GEARS CRUNCH
Oh my Lord. Another one o’ them infernal engines.
(CALLING FROM VAN) I’1l never get used to the gears in these foreign vans. Give me a Morris Minor any day. There’s goodness knows how many bags of cement in the back, Mr Petherbridge.
Excellent. Jedediah, go with Muriel and unload for the workers at the radar site. There’s an extra wall needs building. Round about 1984 I believe.
I’m not getting in that thing, Mr P. Not for love nor money.
That’s why I said to take the horse.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 51
Oh, right. (MOUNTING HORSE) You think of everything Mr P.
Muriel, it’s time your ladies did their bit.
Right you are, Mr Petherbridge. Follow me, young man!
FX: VAN DRIVES OFF, HORSE CANTERS AFTER
Back here soonest, Jedediah! (TO SELF) Have I thought of everything?
FX: DISTORTED EXPLOSION, OFF
(AMUSED) Yes. I believe I have.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 52
Scene 29: EXT. HORSHAM ROAD, PEASE POTTAGE
(L) There it goes again. That ‘time explosion’. It’s decided. You, young Doctor, deal with the alien vessel. Stop the invasion.
(R) Yet another collection of extraterrestrials out to conquer the earth... Why do I get the boring job?
(L) I’ve more experience of temporal anomalies. I’ve more experience full stop. Now, Mel, I assume you have the IT skills your counterpart is lacking...
Lacking? What’s wrong with her?
(R) Actually, I'd prefer this Mel’s help. The other one’s useless. What do we call her, by the way? Mel the Younger? Mini-Mel? Mel minora?
Hey, I’m not some parcel you can pass back and forth.
(L) Young Mel seems rather in thrall to this Petherbridge. I'd like you to keep her away from him for a while.
(R) Who made you boss?
(L) I did.
(R) I still don’t see why I get the aliens. You can’t remember what happened yet.
What does he mean: you can’t remember?
(L) Look, I’ve foiled so many invasions, I don’t recall every Single detail.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 53
(R) Unless dealing with the time disturbance does something to my memory.
(FRUSTRATED) Two of you just make things twice as confusing.
(R) All right. I’1l stop them.. with ‘Mini-Mel’ assistance!
(RAISING VOICE) I asked a question! Won’t one of you tell me what’s going on?
(L) Sorry, Mel. My earlier self and I have ascertained that I am only remembering these events after they happen to him.
(R) We’re in a pocket of time that’s been cut off from the rest of the universe. Cauterised.
(L) And what happens in cauterised time...
(R) ..stays in cauterised time.
Neither of you should be here. This isn’t how I met you.
(L) That’s right. We need to put things back on track.
You’re the wrong Doctors in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Story of my lives.
FX: APPROACHING BIKE, BELL
(R) Here she comes.
Is that..?
(L) Mel. Bush.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 54
Yes, I know. It’s me.
(L) No, Mel. Hide. In that bush. If she’s under some kind of mind control, we’d best not overload her.
(FX: GETTING PUSHED INTO BUSHES) Oof!
(R) Actually, you should probably- Oh, too late.
Oh. There are two of you now?
(R) Yes. This is my... um... twin. We work together. Occasionally.
(FX: GOING INTO BUSHES) Can’t stop. Better just check this foliage. Possible radar interference...
Did he just push someone into that bush?
Another... er... twin. Now. How would you like to meet some aliens?
(FX: WHEELING BIKE, WALKING OFF) Really? I thought nothing exciting ever happened in Pease Pottage. Mr Petherbridge is over at the hall. He did say I could take a break... Go on then. I’m game!
(WALKING OFF) Right, Mel B. Let’s spice up your life!
(FX: MOTLEY DOCTOR AND YOUNG MEL LEAVE. BLUE DOCTOR AND MEL EMERGE FROM BUSHES )
Come on out, Mel. They’ve gone.
That was... me!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 55
Yes. Probably best you don’t meet. We’re in enough trouble with my own timeline.
Where next then, Indigo Jones?
You heard. The Village Hall. I’d very much like to find this Petherbridge. (GOING OFF) And please stop calling me Indigo...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 56
Scene 30: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST
(FX: DOCTOR AND MEL CREEPING THROUGH WOODS, TWIGS SNAPPING, LEAVES RUSTLING)
Shhh! You know, for someone so slight of frame, ‘Mini-Mel’, you do make rather a lot of noise.
Sorry. If I’d known I’d be tramping through woods...
FX: BRANCH BREAKING
Ow. So where are these aliens?
There’s something in the air. Setting my teeth on edge.
Like a thunderstorm brewing. We’re out of the trees at least.
FX: STEPPING OUT OF WOODS ONTO GRASS
According to your radar, their beam reaches just over there. What’s that flag?
The fifteenth hole, I think. Look, someone’s left their clubs.
FX: FLASH OF CHANNEL FORMING
Stay here, Mel. Under cover.
What is that? An orange... doorway? Hanging in the air!
A Valanxium Channel. On a golf course. How appropriate. Now what are they doing here?
Who?
Mardaks. An entire species dedicated to one of the most despicable occupations in the civilised universe.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 57
What are they? Robbers? (BEAT) Arms dealers? (BEAT, WILD GUESS)
Pirates?
No, Mel. (DISDAINFULLY) Business consultants...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 58
Scene 31: INT. MARDAK SHIP, CONFERENCE ROOM
FX: AUDENCE OF MARDAKS WATCHING PRESENTATION
(FX: ON MIC, PRESENTING) And the next slide please, Deerek.
FX: CLICK OF PROJECTOR
(FX: ON MIC) Sorry. This chart’s a bit busy. But if you look at your handouts...
FX: RUSTLING PAPERS
(FX: ON MIC) You’1ll see the imagineered valanxium yield is twenty times expenditure. It’s all low-hanging fruit on this one, people.
(SOTTO) Next slide.
So. We dynamically steer ourselves like any client. Keep our prob-jective CLEVER.
That’s Costed. Leveraged. Efficient. Value-added. Essential. And Reversible.
(COUGHS) Facilitator Vaneesh.. If we could wrap this up? The Channel’s open.
FX: MARDAKS START LEAVING ROOM, MUMBLING, CHAIRS SCRAPING
(OVER NOISE, RACING THROUGH SLIDES) In conclusion. I want alpha players with a can-do headset! Be fifteen percent better than your best! Remember our brand-message: Delivering tomorrow, today!
FX: NOISE OF DEPARTING MARDAKS
(OVER NOISE) Above all - have fun!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 59
Scene 32: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST, EDGE OF GOLF COURSE
What’s valanxium?
A very dangerous, very volatile element. And an extremely valuable one.
Why? What’s it for?
It saves time. It can be used to extrude short-range passage through the vortex. The Mardaks’ primitive technology allows hops of several thousand miles. With zero travel costs.
I see.
The only trouble is, valanxium is chronically unstable.
You mean, it keeps falling to bits?
(IMPATIENTLY) No, I mean its chronons are liable to come unfixed from the timeline. Do pay attention. And punching holes in the vortex willy-nilly is never a good idea.
I understand the bit about dangerous, at least. So that’s their business? Selling these Channels?
The ability to ship anything instantly from its point of origin to its point of use. Convenient, yes. But...
Isn’t that a good thing? Scientific advancement?
Not always. It renders the game of golf pointless for a start.
(BEAT) Perhaps that’s a bad example.
As Francis Bacon put it: ‘Travel, in the younger sort, is a part of education; in the elder, a part of experience.’
FX: MARDAKS MARCH FROM TUNNEL, OFF
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 60
Oh wow... Aliens... Real aliens. They’re purple!

Used to be grey. A focus group decided this particular shade of violet ‘created impact with the client base while maintaining a non-threatening aura’. So they bio-engineered it into their DNA. Everyone else just thinks it clashes terribly with whatever they wear. Those mustard business suits are a mistake...
(SOTTO) People in glass houses... (ALOUD) What are they carrying?
Looks like digging equipment. Mini-Mel, pass me that golf bag...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 61
Scene 33: EXT. VALANXIUM CHANNEL, GOLF COURSE
FX: MARDAK TROOPS — ABOUT TWENTY — SETTING UP DIGGERS
(FX: BEEPING SCANNER) OK then. Team Aptitude. Start over here.
Gervin and Wardek, that’s your lot. Move it.

VANEESH: (FX: ON MIC) Sorry. This chart’s a bit busy. But if you look at your handouts...
VANEESH: (FX: ON MIC) You’1ll see the imagineered valanxium yield is twenty times expenditure. It’s all low-hanging fruit on this one, people.
VANEESH: (SOTTO) Next slide.
VANEESH: So. We dynamically steer ourselves like any client. Keep our prob-jective CLEVER.
VANEESH: That’s Costed. Leveraged. Efficient. Value-added. Essential. And Reversible.
KALLAK: (COUGHS) Facilitator Vaneesh.. If we could wrap this up? The Channel’s open.
VANEESH: (OVER NOISE, RACING THROUGH SLIDES) In conclusion. I want alpha players with a can-do headset! Be fifteen percent better than your best! Remember our brand-message: Delivering tomorrow, today!
VANEESH: (OVER NOISE) Above all - have fun!
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 59
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 32: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST, EDGE OF GOLF COURSE
YOUNG MEL: What’s valanxium?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: A very dangerous, very volatile element. And an extremely valuable one.
YOUNG MEL: Why? What’s it for?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: It saves time. It can be used to extrude short-range passage through the vortex. The Mardaks’ primitive technology allows hops of several thousand miles. With zero travel costs.
YOUNG MEL: I see.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: The only trouble is, valanxium is chronically unstable.
YOUNG MEL: You mean, it keeps falling to bits?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (IMPATIENTLY) No, I mean its chronons are liable to come unfixed from the timeline. Do pay attention. And punching holes in the vortex willy-nilly is never a good idea.
YOUNG MEL: I understand the bit about dangerous, at least. So that’s their business? Selling these Channels?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: The ability to ship anything instantly from its point of origin to its point of use. Convenient, yes. But...
YOUNG MEL: Isn’t that a good thing? Scientific advancement?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: Not always. It renders the game of golf pointless for a start.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (BEAT) Perhaps that’s a bad example.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: As Francis Bacon put it: ‘Travel, in the younger sort, is a part of education; in the elder, a part of experience.’
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 60
YOUNG MEL: Oh wow... Aliens... Real aliens. They’re purple!
MOTLEY DOCTOR: Used to be grey. A focus group decided this particular shade of violet ‘created impact with the client base while maintaining a non-threatening aura’. So they bio-engineered it into their DNA. Everyone else just thinks it clashes terribly with whatever they wear. Those mustard business suits are a mistake...
YOUNG MEL: (SOTTO) People in glass houses... (ALOUD) What are they carrying?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: Looks like digging equipment. Mini-Mel, pass me that golf bag...
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 61
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 33: EXT. VALANXIUM CHANNEL, GOLF COURSE
VANEESH: (FX: BEEPING SCANNER) OK then. Team Aptitude. Start over here.
KALLAK: Gervin and Wardek, that’s your lot. Move it.
VANEESH: And Team Stardrive. Start over there.
KALLAK: Verlek. Craden. Get going.
VANEESH: We should meet up fifty metres below... here. First to hit valanxium gets a HomeCorp Handshake!
KALLAK: (ASIDE) Why don’t you just call them by their names, Vaneesh?
VANEESH: They love the teamsmanship. Look at them go.
KALLAK: We never used to need... ‘incentivisation’, back in the day. We did what we did for the glory of HomeCorp.
VANEESH: It’s a new world, Kallak. These guys all want D.B.A.’s. Doctorates in Business Application guarantee a better pay-grade than Ship Captain. With my lead-spiration, they’1ll outrank you soon. Engage as Facilitators on client-worlds.
KALLAK: Yeah? They’1l still need ships to get there.
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 62
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 34: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST, EDGE OF GOLF COURSE
MOTLEY DOCTOR: Right. Enough covert observation. Let’s get their attention.
YOUNG MEL: How are you going to do that?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: From this distance? I think... a five iron.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (FX: SWING AND THWACK) Fore!
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 63
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 35: INT. PEASE POTTAGE VILLAGE HALL
PETHERBRIDGE: Pease Pottage hot. Pease Pottage cold. Pease Pottage in the pot, four days old.
BLUE DOCTOR: Mr Petherbridge. You’re a difficult man to trace. Everywhere and nowhere.
PETHERBRIDGE: Doctor. Would it be ever so gauche to say... I’ve been expecting you?
BLUE DOCTOR: Hardly original. But in your case, I believe you have. Where’s my TARDIS. Our TARDISes.
PETHERBRIDGE: And you’ve brought the delightful Miss Bush. Let me see how she turns out.
MEL: Who are you? And what have you done to Pease Pottage?
PETHERBRIDGE: (FX: WALKING OVER) Charming. Utterly charming. And in answer to your question, as chair of the Heritage Society, I am placing Pease Pottage at the centre of things.
BLUE DOCTOR: Why would you want to do that? Why do you even have a Heritage Society? Forgive me Mel, but nothing much ever happened here.
PETHERBRIDGE: On the contrary Doctor. Everything happens here. (FX: OPENING DOOR) I’11 show you.
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 64
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 36: EXT. PEASE POTTAGE VILLAGE GREEN [CONTINUOUS]
PETHERBRIDGE: (WALKING OUTSIDE) A celebration. A confluence of history. My own small recital pales in comparison.
MEL: (FOLLOWING) Where did all the people come from? That arch wasn’t there when we arrived. What does it say?
BLUE DOCTOR: ‘Victoria Regina.’ Spelt with dahlias. How... refined.
PETHERBRIDGE: Her Majesty’s visit. 1837 I believe. We need to be just a smidgen soonev...
MEL: Doctor... I can feel it. I can see the threads. It’s like sorting through my memory.
PETHERBRIDGE: Oh very good. She has potential, Doctor.
BLUE DOCTOR: What are you doing to her? Stop it. Now
MEL: I- I’m OK. Just an odd sensation for a moment.
PETHERBRIDGE: Pease Pottage. The name is so very... English. They say it comes from the pease porridge, you know. They fed it to convicts, passing through the gate.
BLUE DOCTOR: Like many folk stories, I believe that particular explanation is apocryphal.
PETHERBRIDGE: Really? You should ask our nineteenth century convicts for their opinion.
PETHERBRIDGE: (FX: JUST OFF, HORSE-DRAWN WAGON ARRIVES, CHAINED CONVICTS DISEMBARK )
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 65
MEL: Look. A wagon. With guards. And prisoners.
PETHERBRIDGE: There they are. Half a dozen reprobates destined for the naval prison at Lewes. Disembarking for rations at the toll-gate.
MEL: There’s Jed. He’s chained up.
BLUE DOCTOR: Actually, Mel. That young man’s over here as well.
JED: (FX: DISMOUNTING) Blimey. That’s what I look like.
PETHERBRIDGE: Thank you, Jedediah. I’1ll take the horse. (FX: MOUNTING HORSE) Been a while since I rode. Got the flintlocks, lad? Pass them
PETHERBRIDGE: up.
JED: (HANDING GUNS TO PETHERBRIDGE) Here, Mr P. How can I be over there? And ‘ere? It don’t sit right in my head.
BLUE DOCTOR: I’m not surprised. It could be catastrophic. You need to get right away.
MEL: The Doctor knows what he’s talking about.
PETHERBRIDGE: Indeed, Jed. Back to the woods with you.
JED: (RUNNING OFF) I ain’t arguing. This is too... unnatural.
BLUE DOCTOR: You’re picking and choosing moments from history. But how? And why?
PETHERBRIDGE: (FX: COCKING PISTOLS) Two guards. Two shots. Master Thurwell just completed his most important task yet. Securing his own freedom.
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 66
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 37: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST, EDGE OF GOLF COURSE
VANEESH: Greetings Earthling. Please do not be alarmed. My name’s Vaneesh, and I’1l be your Invasion Facilitator for the duration of this incursion. (WINCING) We’1ll overlook the projectiles for now.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: I’ll put this simply. Leave. This. Planet.
VANEESH: Lesser species can be disorientated when they come under Mardak HomeCorp control. So we’ve prepared a welcome pack for all new affiliates.
MOTLEY DOCTOR: I don’t want your brochure. Pack up your buckets and spades and
MOTLEY DOCTOR: go.
YOUNG MEL: Doctor, aren’t you being a bit [rude?]
MOTLEY DOCTOR: Leave this to me, mini-Mel.
VANEESH: Sorry, I can’t expect an inferior life-form to understand the complexities of our prob-jective. (BEAT) Who were you talking to?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: Prob-jective?
VANEESH: Project objective. As I say, a native-
MOTLEY DOCTOR: (INTERRUPTING) You’re mistaken, Facilitator. I’m not
MOTLEY DOCTOR: indigenous.
VANEESH: One moment.
YOUNG MEL: Doctor. What’s she doing?
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 67
MOTLEY DOCTOR: A bioscan.
KALLAK: (WALKING UP) Trouble, Vaneesh? Don’t tell me - residential objections?
MOTLEY DOCTOR: I’m not a resident.
VANEESH: Higher species. Competition. That rebrands my perspective...
MOTLEY DOCTOR: I hate to say I told you so...
YOUNG MEL: (SOTTO) I don’t think you do...
VANEESH: Any threat to Mardak monopoly must be removed. With extreme prejudice. Kallak.
KALLAK: Facilitator?
VANEESH: Incinerate the competition.
YOUNG MEL: No!
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 68
DOCTOR WHO: Scene 38: EXT. PEASE POTTAGE VILLAGE GREEN
PETHERBRIDGE: (CALLING) Guards. Your attention!
MEL: Don’t shoot them. You mustn’t!
BLUE DOCTOR: Mel, Be careful.
PETHERBRIDGE: They’ve vanished. You’re improving at this, Melanie. Not a shot need be fired.
MEL: No!
BLUE DOCTOR: It’s all right Mel. He just broke the prisoners’ chains.
PETHERBRIDGE: (CALLING) Release your associates, young Jed.
JED: (CALLING OVER) Thank you sir. We’re in your debt sir.
PETHERBRIDGE: Good. You man. Poacher Pete is it? Hold the girl. I needn’t remind you who has the weapons.
MEL: (STRUGGLING) Get off me you-
PETHERBRIDGE: The rest of you. The... ‘magistrate’ in the blue coat.
BLUE DOCTOR: (STRUGGLING) I don’t know what you hope to achieve with this petty display of brute force...
PETHERBRIDGE: A lesson in causality, Doctor. I tell these men to tie you to
PETHERBRIDGE: that cart. So they do. (BEAT, SHOUTS) Do it!
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 69
BLUE DOCTOR: (STRUGGLING) No!
PETHERBRIDGE: Tie him, Master Thurwell.
BLUE DOCTOR: (STRUGGLING) Unhand me. Let me go.
PETHERBRIDGE: Behind you. Crates of gunpowder. The fuse will give you one minute. Maybe two. Time for you to think on this conundrum. This cart was stolen by these men. Yet I’ve only just freed them for that purpose.
MEL: Stop it! Just let him go!
PETHERBRIDGE: As I say. A lesson in causality. And how I control it.
BLUE DOCTOR: What are you, Petherbridge?
PETHERBRIDGE: Goodbye Doctor, I’ve a reality to arrange. (FX: DISASSEMBLING FLINTLOCK, TROTTING HORSE) Here’s a flint, Jedediah. Light the fuse. Yah!
BLUE DOCTOR: Jed. You don’t have to listen to him.
JED: (FX: STRIKING FLINT) How- how do you all know who I am?
MEL: Please, Jed. Don’t do it!
JED: Sorry, Miss. No choice, Miss. Don’t think I ever had.
MEL: No!
MEL: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 70

elements.text: PART THREE
CONTINUES INTO:
Scene 39: EXT. PEASE POTTAGE VILLAGE GREEN [CONTINUOUS]
FX: B/G FIZZ OF FUSE THROUGH
Lads. We need to be away before the beaksmen twig we’re on the hop. And before the very loud bang.
What about this one?
(STRUGGLING) Let... me... go!
Firebrand ain’t you? Pretty one too. Yeah. Leave her Pete.
(GOING OFF) Who was that toff on ‘orseback?
Dunno. Seemed familiar. Cover your ears for the bang, missy! (RUNNING OFF) Head for the wood, lads!
FX: CONVICTS RUN OFF
Doctor. Let me-
Don’t come any closer Mel. This gunpowder could explode at any second.
What did Petherbridge say..? Causality.. I did something. I saved the guards.
(WORKING ON ROPES) Whatever you’re thinking, don’t let him into your mind. Mel - get back!
Doctor... I can see it.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 71
See what? If I can just free one hand... I taught Harry a thing or two about knots...
Everything that happens... The past.
(STRUGGLING WITH ROPE) It’s coming loose. Wait!
I can see the links. I can make things change...
Mel! Don’t do it.
What if Jed didn’t want you to die? What if he knew you’d escape? What if he tied a slip knot?
There! I’m free. Now just to pull out this fuse... and snuff it! To ensure I don’t. (FX: REMOVING FUSE AND EXTINGUISHING FIZZ)
Hey presto...
FX: DOCTOR JUMPS DOWN FROM CART
I did it!
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 72
Scene 40: EXT. FIELD 1940 (SITE OF FUTURE GOLF COURSE)
FX: SOUNDS OF A DOZEN LADIES DIGGING
FX: WHEELING TROLLEY
Here we are ladies. Tea and lardy johns. One flask between three. Mugs on the trolley.
FX: TOOLS PUT DOWN, LADIES GET MUGS
Thank you Ma’am. Good of you to wheel this all the way out here.
No trouble at all dear. How are you getting on, Millicent?
Just about finished, ma’am. Six holes. Ten feet down. Exactly as marked on the plan.
We can always rely on the ladies of the Institute.
Happy to get our hands dirty. Digging for England, what? Good practice turning over the cricket pitch last year.
I remember.
A few holes in the Rogersons’ potato field are a cinch compared to that.
It will all be worth it in the end.
You think Jerry’s really on his way?
Our Captain Petherbridge had an urgent communiqué from the War Office. This field will become strategically significant.
Good-oh, Ma’am. Glad to do our bit. (CALLING) Back to it, girls. A few more feet.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 73
FX: LADIES GOING OFF AND PICKING UP TOOLS
There'll be extra rations laid on at the Swan for you all.
No need for that, Ma’am. Let the youngsters and old folk have them.
That’s the spirit. That’s how we’1ll win the war! Carry on ladies.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 74
Any threat to a Mardak monopoly must be removed. With extreme prejudice. Kallak.
Facilitator?
Incinerate the competition.
No!
CONTINUES INTO:
Scene 41: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST, EDGE OF GOLF COURSE [CONTINUOUS ]
FX: B/G HUM OF VALANXIUM CHANNEL
Erm. You can’t do that, Vaneesh. Competitor incineration requires prior approval from the HomeCorp. He might have assets we need to strip.
Sensible fellow... Kallak was it? My assets are all in my head. No material value, but incalculable worth. (ASIDE) I’m afraid I can’t count you as an asset, sorry, mini-Mel.
I’d probably be offended if I’d any idea what was going on...
Who are you talking to? Anyway... my colleague may be correct. Scan shows no weapons. No known affiliated species. What are you? An independent?
You could say that.
Have you a... communicator somewhere? Wait... Is this part of the training?
What do you think?
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 75
Kallak... You said HomeCorp would be watching...
Don’t ask me. I’m just a humble Ship’s Captain.
‘Scuse us. My... subordinate and I just need to micro-conference.
Don’t mind me. Micro-conference away.
(ASIDE, TO KALLAK) What do you think? A covert Assessor? I've heard HomeCorp plant them on training runs. Just the sort of left-field challenge they’d throw in to test green-sky thinking...
Your call Vaneesh. If he’s got local knowledge, he could be useful.
(FX: PDA BEEPING) I’1l just check my flowchart... Competitors... Independent consultants... (TO DOCTOR) Sorry. Shan’t keep you.
I’m not going anywhere.
Doctor? Are you really going to help them!
(CLOSE, TO MEL) Don’t worry mini-Mel. I know what I’m doing. Have you noticed?
(CLOSE) What?
(CLOSE) They can’t see you. Which might have been an advantage if you weren’t such a liability. As it is, you’re invisible and ineffectual.
(CLOSE) You know, you’re a very rude man.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 76
(CLOSE) No point beating about the... bush. Go back to the village. Find my... assistant. Tell him it’s this Valanxium Channel causing the trouble.
(CLOSE) You don’t want my help?
(CLOSE) Sorry, mini-Mel. Too risky. I’11 shut it down and send the Mardaks on their way. Make sure he knows - I solve both problems after all.
Sorry to keep you... erm, who were you again?
I am known as the Doctor.

Me too. We’ve all got DBA’s these days, so I don’t bother with the title. OK. So. I can onboard an independent consultant without HomeCorp authorisation so long as the costing’s within point five percent of budget total.
Don’t worry. There’s no charge.
Step this way. I’ve some forms on the ship.
You sure about this Vaneesh?
I’m sure I don’t need you questioning my every decision!
Via your Valanxium Channel? A delta configuration if I’m not mistaken.
You are HomeCorp. I knew it. A sub-five-thousand with delta protocols. Best-practice efficiency, I thought.
Off I pop, then. Keep doing as you’re told. (POINTEDLY) Everyone.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 77
Yes, Doctor.
FX: DOCTOR ZIPS THROUGH CHANNEL
Carry on digging Kallak. I’ve an Assessor to impress.
You heard the Facilitator. Let’s get on with the real work.
FX: DIGGING RESTARTS
Great. I get to meet aliens and they can’t even see me.
(WALKING OFF) I guess I’m not cut out for adventuring. Mr Petherbridge will be wondering where I am. He’s always got things for me to do...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 78
Scene 42: EXT. FIELD (FUTURE SITE OF GOLF COURSE)
FX: SOUNDS OF A DOZEN LADIES FILLING HOLES
FX: CYCLE AND TROLLEY
Here we are ladies. Tea and lardy johns. One flask between three. Mugs on the trolley.
FX: TOOLS BEING PUT DOWN AS LADIES GET REFRESHMENTS
Thank you Ma’am. Good of you to wheel this all the way out here.
No trouble at all dear. How are you getting on, Millicent?
Just about finished, ma’am. Blast caps attached. Holes almost filled. Detonation cords are all connected here.
We can always rely on the ladies of the Institute.
Happy to get our hands dirty. Digging for England, what? Good practice turning over the cricket pitch last... (BREAKS OFF, CONFUSED) You know, I could have sworn we dug this field over too.
Really, dear?
Must have dreamt it! This bally war. The days become one
sometimes.
Don’t I know it, dear.
(CALLING) Back to it, girls. A few more shovels and we’re done.
FX: LADIES GOING OFF AND PICKING UP TOOLS
There'll be extra rations laid on at the Swan for you all.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 79
No need for that Ma’am. Let the youngsters and old folk have them.
Somehow, I knew you’d say that. (BEAT) It’s... so good to see you again, Millicent.
The.. planning meeting was only last night... (BEAT) You all right, Ma’am? You seem a little distracted.
Sorry. As you say, it’s one long day. Carry on ladies.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 80
Scene 43: INT. MARDAK SHIP
(FX: VALANXIUM CHANNEL HUM, FLASHES AS DOCTOR AND VANEESH EMERGE )
Just wait here. I’1l formalise the paperwork. Bear with me, it’s my first invasion — as if you didn’t know.
Well, you’re doing very well. So this is your Channel control chamber?
I’m sure you’re familiar with the set-up. Watercooler’s over there. Take a seat. There’s the comms. Buzz if you need anything.
FX: SHIP DOOR SWISH
Valanxium. Such a clumsy means of travel. And a dangerous one. (FX: TYPING AND BEEPS THROUGH) I do like a co-operative computer.
Valanxium pod in the hold... Twenty... twenty-five units. The Channel’s using... point zero zero two per minute.
Let’s see... More unstable than I thought. They haven’t even shielded it correctly. Some fine adjustments to the settings, I think. Can’t have this Channel left open once we get back...
And a communicator, eh? Let’s see if there’s anyone out there worth talking to.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 81
Scene 44: EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF WW I ARMY CAMP 1915, HORSHAM ROAD
FX: B/G TROOP DRILL THROUGHOUT
1915. The British Army encampment. I’ve saved this particular task for you, Muriel.
Look at them, Mr Petherbridge. Our boys. They are magnificent. I thought I might see my Francis, but he went over in 1914...
Now I don’t want you upsetting yourself. It will all be worth it in the end.
Seeing Millicent. Seeing all my ladies again. It brings it all back. (BEAT) We thought this was the War to end all Wars. But there we were. Twenty years later. It happened all over again.
History has no mercy, Mrs Wilberforce. No conscience. (BEAT) Now. The... detonators?
Back then. Back now, I mean. The first time. I wanted to go over. Volunteer. Francis was so particular about his tea, I thought they’d never get it right without me...
The blasting caps and cords are in the store behind the officers’ tents. I shall occupy them while you fill this kitbag.
Of course I couldn’t go. There was Frank Junior to consider. Two years old. It was hard enough he never saw his daddy again.
Now, Muriel. I told you not to fret. If you like, I’1ll give this job to Jedediah?
No, Mr Petherbridge. Stapleton. Please. Let me do this.
If you’re absolutely certain...
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 82
Look at them. So eager. So keen to get to Flanders. Wipers was the last place he.. (BEAT) When will I see him? My Francis?
It’s... not quite time for that yet.
No. Of course. I have to collect these things... and then...
And then, your friend Millicent can pop them in the holes.
When you explained before.. it all made sense. But I can’t seem to fit it together now. How does it work again?
Now, now. Chin up Muriel. Best foot forward. Don’t forget what I said-
Yes, Mr Petherbridge. It’ll all be worth it in the end.
FX: WILBERFORCE TAKES BAG AND WALKS OFF
Indeed it will, my dear. Indeed it will.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 83
Scene 45: EXT. BUCHAN HILL FOREST
FX: WALKING THROUGH UNDERGROWTH
Oh no... I’1l be late! Why am I in these woods again?
(ARRIVING) Melanie! My own Melanie.
I’m not talking to you, Jed. Not after... (BEAT) Why was I cross with you?
Dunno, missy. Always something it seems. Tell you what, come to the Swan with me tonight. I’1l make amends. Whatever it is I’ve done.
Seventies night isn’t it?
Could do with an ale. Just seen meself being dragged through the gate in chains.
You say the strangest things. Mind you, I’ve just seen something very odd myself... I think. Can’t quite remember now... Something... purple?
Made me ponder. When I first got here.. me and the lads hid out in the woods. Then old Petherbridge turned up. With his proposal.
Every day’s the same to me. Usually. Today’s been different... I think. There was someone... a Doctor?
I try not to think about it. Ties me brains in knots it does.
That’s the thing. I don’t think about it at all.. I can’t. But I’m sure there’s a reason I’m here. Something happened. On the golf course.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 84
Back and forth. Back and forth he has me running, like a bob- tailed bunny. But it’1ll all be worth it (WITH MEL) in the end.
(JOINS IN) In the end... How long have you known me Jed?
Sometimes I think we just met. Others... it’s like I’ve known you all my life, Melanie. But this never happened in my life. That’s what I mean, see. Best not to think about it.
All your life. Yes, I remember. You can see it, can’t you?
Laid out like a story in my head. I know where I was born. Where I lived. Where I... died.
What did he promise you, Jed?
Freedom.
I know I’ve a past. A family. I know what’s happening out in the world... 1987.. But, what’s the future, Jed?
We’ve talked about this before. You never remember.
No. I don’t. I see where everybody’s story goes but my own.
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 85
Scene 46: EXT. OUTSIDE ATC STATION
FX: WALKING ON GRAVEL PATH
If you did do something back there, and it wasn’t purely down to my escapology skills...
I told you Doctor. I could see the possibilities unfolding in front of me.
Don’t do it again, please? We don’t know what the effect might be. Your younger self is not herself at all. If you see what I mean.
You think Petherbridge is controlling her?
Among other things. Somehow he’s thrown causality out the window. And he didn’t even have to open it first. (STOPPING) It’s centred here.
The radar station?
Have you noticed? The walk gets shorter every time. (FX: OPENS DOOR)
THE WRONG DOCTORS by Matt Fitton Page 86
Scene 47: INT. ATC STATION [CONTINUOUS]
FX: B/G AS BEFORE
(JUST OFF) Hello? Anyone home?
(ENTERING) Look at this set-up! Now here’s something I can understand. A computer keyboard.
FX: TAPPING AT KEYS - COMPUTER BEEPS IN RESPONSE
(FOLLOWING) Yes. Let’s put those much-vaunted skills of yours to the test, eh?
(TYPING) I’ve never actually been here before... I certainly never worked here.
Most of this equipment shouldn’t be here either. It’s far more than a simple tracking station.
(FX: TYPING) Strange. These systems seem very familiar... There. Done it.
Done what?
Opened a back-door to the shell-program. You can see the subroutines... I think that’s a memory map, but I’ve got to admit I’ve no idea what these processes are doing.
Melanie Bush. You are a marvel. If you didn’t exist I’d have to invent you!
Thanks, Indigo!
I told you, Mel, it’s Inigo- (BREAKS OFF, SUDDENLY REALIZING) Perfect recall. You said when you aligned events... It was like arranging your memories.
